title: Protocol for highly selective transgene expression through the flip-excision switch system by using a unilateral spacer sequence in rodents

Step-by-step method details
Construction of transfer plasmids
Timing: 7 days
In this section, we describe how to construct the transfer plasmids for preparation of AAV vectors.
Prepare the plasmid containing a multicloning site (MCS) between the cytomegalovirus early enhancer/chicken β-actin (CAG) promoter and woodchuck hepatitis virus posttranscriptional regulatory element (WPRE) sequence connecting to human growth hormone polyadenylation signal, resulting in pAAV-CAG-MCS-WPRE. Place a pair of loxP-lox2272 sequences into the MCS of the plasmid in the opposite direction with an alternate order by using synthetic DNA.
Construct the transfer plasmid termed pAAV-CAG-FLEX-GFP by inserting GFP cDNA in the inverted orientation between a pair of the double recognition site sequences in pAAV-CAG-MCS-WPRE by using a Gibson Assembly Cloning Kit (New England Biolabs).
If necessary, replace the CAG promoter with another suitable promoter, such as the human elongation factor-1α (EF1α) promoter.
For other transfer plasmids, replace the GFP cDNA with other genes of interest, such as red fluorescent protein (RFP; mCherry), a variant of channelrhodopsin-2 fused to Venus (ChRWR/Venus), or a mutant form of human muscarinic M4 acetylcholine receptor connected to 2A-GFP (hM4Di/2A/GFP).
Cleave the pAAV-CAG-FLEX-GFP plasmid with EcoRI or ClaI at either side of the inverted transgene and insert the USS of approximately 750 bp using Gibson Assembly Cloning Kit. For instance, the gene cassette encoding TurboFP635, a mutant of TurboFP635 (mTurboFP635) or marine copepod luciferase (Luc) are inserted between the loxP and lox2272 sites either at the 5′- or 3′-end of the transgene, resulting in pAAV-CAG-FLEX/5′USS-GFP or pAAV-CAG-FLEX/3′USS-GFP.
Transform E.coli DH5α strain with the respective plasmids, pick up colonies, culture each colony in 3 mL of LB medium containing 50 μg/mL of ampicillin at 37°C for 8 h, and then scale up to 500 mL to be cultured for 16 h.

Prepare the plasmids using the NucleoBond Xtra Maxi EF Kit (Macherey-Nagel).
Note: 108 μg of transfection grade plasmid is necessary for transfecting eighteen 100-mm dishes of HEK293T cells. The pAAV-CAG-FLEX-GFP, pAAV-CAG-FLEX/5′USS-GFP, and pAAV-CAG-FLEX/3′USS-GFP can be obtained from Addgene (#197883, #197884, and #197885, respectively).
Pause point: Plasmids can be stored at −20°C or −80°C for years.
Preparation of AAV vectors
Timing: 9 days
In this section, we describe how to produce AAV serotype 2 vectors (AAV-CAG-FLEX-GFP and AAV-CAG-FLEX/3′USS-GFP) based on AAV Helper-Free System (Agilent Technologies) by transfecting the plasmids into HEK293T cells with the calcium phosphate co-precipitation method. Transfection into the cells is also carried-out with polyethylenimine or lipofectamine. The vectors are purified by using the CsCl gradient ultracentrifugation. Purification processes are summarized in Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]. The procedures for preparation of AAV vectors are also described in some previous reports.5[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib5],10[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib10],11[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib11]

Figure 2. Purification processes of AAV vector particles
The crude viral vector lysate, which is prepared from the cultured cell medium after DNA transfection, is purified with the first round of CsCl gradient ultracentrifugation by using a near-vertical tube rotor (NVT 65) with quick-seal tubes (A), and then the second round of CsCl gradient ultracentrifugation by using a swinging-bucket rotor (SW 55Ti) with thinwall polypropylene tubes (B). The solution containing the particles is collected as drops through the needle inserted into the bottom of the tubes. The solution is dialyzed against PBS by using a dialysis cassette (C), and vector particles are concentrated by ultrafiltration through a membrane filter (D).

Note: 6 μg of each plasmid is required for transfection per a 100-mm dish. In the case of a 150-mm dish, 16.8 μg of each plasmid is required.
table:files/protocols_protocol_3088_10.csv
Note: A total of 18 mL of the transfection mix solution is used for eighteen 100-mm dishes.

Culture HEK293T cells in 100-mm cell culture dishes containing 7 mL of DMEM supplemented with 10% FBS and penicillin-streptomycin in a 37°C, 5% CO2 humidified incubator.
Note: The cell culture medium should be stored at 4°C, and pre-warmed to 37°C before use.
The cells should be subcultured before becoming confluent on the plate.
Maintain the cells until approximately 80% confluent.
Aspirate medium, wash cells once with 5 mL of PBS, and remove residual medium in the plate.
Detach cells with 2 mL of Trypsin-EDTA solution for 3 min at 37°C.
Neutralize the enzymatic activity of trypsin by adding 10 mL of pre-warmed culture medium and suspend the cells by gentle pipetting.
Transfer the suspended cells to 50-mL tubes.
Centrifuge the tubes at 300 × g for 5 min at 4°C and discard the supernatant.
Resuspend the cell pellet in an appropriate volume of pre-warmed cell culture medium.
Add the suspended cells to six 100-mm cell culture dishes containing 7 mL of cell culture medium (approximately 1 mL to each dish).
Note: After dropping the suspended cells into each dish, shake the dish gently to spread the cells over culture medium.
Incubate the cells for 24 h in a 37°C, 5% CO2-humidified incubator.
Prepare a transfection mixture to transfect the plasmids into the cells in eighteen 100-mm culture dishes.
Mix 108 μg for each of AAV transfer (pAAV-CAG-FLEX-GFP or pAAV-CAG-FLEX/3′USS-GFP), pRep/Cap, and pHelper plasmids (2 mg/mL for each plasmid) in 8.1 mL of ddH2O and 0.9 mL of 2.5 M calcium chloride solution in a 50-mL tube.
Add 9 mL of 2× HBSP solution dropwise, mixing gently with the vortex mixer.
Incubate the mixture for 5 min to form the DNA-HBSP complex.

Note: The 10× HBSP stock solution should be stored at 4°C, and the 2× HBSP solution should be stored at −20°C. After thawing, the solution should be stored at 4°C. The 2.5M Calcium chloride solution should be stored at −20°C.
Drop 1 mL of the mixture into each 100-mm culture dish containing 7 mL of culture medium, and shake the dish gently.
Incubate the cells for 18 h in a 37°C, 5% CO2 humidified incubator.
Aspirate the medium, add 7 mL of the pre-warmed fresh culture medium, and incubate the cells for 2 more days.
Remove the medium, add 2 mL of PBS per dish, strip the cells with a cell scraper, and collect them into a 50-mL tube.
Centrifuge at 300 × g for 5 min at 4°C and remove the supernatant.
Add 10 mL of PBS, wash cells, and remove supernatant by centrifugation (300 × g) for 5 min at 4°C.
Pause point: The resultant cell pellet can be stored at −80°C.
Resuspend the cell pellet in 6.5 mL of TBS.
For cell lysis, freeze the pellet in liquid N2 for 5–10 min and thaw in a 37°C water bath for 5–10 min. Shake occasionally the suspension to lysate the cells and release vector particles.
Repeat the freeze-thaw cycle three times.
Pause point: Frozen cell suspensions prior to the third thaw can be stored at −80°C.
Add benzonase into the tube to a final concentration of 50 U/mL and mix gently the solution.
Place the tube in a water bath at 37°C for 30 min to degrade DNA in the cell lysate.
Add 65 μL of 0.5 M EDTA to stop the reaction.
Centrifuge at 3,500 × g for 15 min at 4°C.

Transfer the supernatant containing vector particles to a 15-mL tube. The volume of the supernatant is approximately 5–7 mL.
Note: Store the supernatant at 4°C during the preparation of the CsCl gradient.
Fill up the supernatant to 8.11 mL with PBS, and add 4.59 mL of saturated CsCl/PBS solution (1.24 g/mL) (total volume 12.7 mL).
Transfer the AAV vector solution to a quick-seal tube using a Pasteur pipette.
Add saturated CsCl/PBS solution into the tube until the surface reaches the tube’s hole neck, and then check the balance.
Seal the tube top using a heat-sealer.
Centrifuge in a Beckman NVT 65 rotor at 287,000 × g (55,000 rpm) for 24 h at 16°C.
Note: After ultracentrifugation, carefully carry the rotor to avoid collapsing the gradient.
table:files/protocols_protocol_3088_11.csv
Insert a 22-gauge needle into the top of the tube for venting, and another 22-gauge needle into the bottom of the tube.
Collect approximately 1.0 mL of drop solution from the bottom into a 1.5 mL tube (1–10 fractions).
Pool the fractions containing vector particles to a thinwall polypropylene tube and balance with CsCl/PBS solution (0.55 g/mL).
table:files/protocols_protocol_3088_12.csv
Note: In our protocol, the second to sixth fractions usually contain vector particles. Real-time quantitative PCR can be performed using each fraction as a template to confirm the peak fraction.
Centrifuge in a Beckman SW 55Ti rotor at 287,000 × g (48,700 rpm) for 24 h at 16°C.
Note: After ultracentrifugation, carefully carry the rotor to avoid collapsing the gradient.
Pierce the bottom of the tube with a 22-gauge needle to collect 0.5 mL of drop solution from the bottom into a 1.5 mL tube (1–10 fractions).
Take 1 μL of solution from each fraction, dilute 1000-fold with ddH2O, and use 4 μL of each dilution for the quantitative PCR as a template.

Dialyze the collected vector solution with a Slide-A-Lyzer G2 dialysis cassette in 1 L of PBS at 4°C twice for 2 h.
Dialyze the vector solution once again for 12–16 h at 4°C in 1 L PBS.
Wet the membrane filter of Vivaspin Turbo 4 by adding 2–3 mL of PBS, centrifuge at 3,500 × g for 1 min at 4°C, and discard the flow-through PBS.
Centrifuge the vector solution using the Vivaspin Turbo 4 at 3,500 × g for 30–45 min at 4°C until the volume reaches about 100 μL.
Note: Usually, the 4th to 7th fractions are collected after the vector titration.
Collect the solution into a 1.5-mL tube.
Centrifuge at 13,000 × g for 20 min at 4°C to remove any protein residues.
Collect the supernatant solution (approximately 50–100 μL) containing AAV particles to a 1.5-mL tube.
The vector solution is aliquoted into 5–10 μL and stored at −80°C for at least 1 year.
Note: Take the solution of 2 μL for vector titration.
Prepare a standard curve with AAV transfer plasmid (pAAV-CAG-FLEX-GFP or pAAV-CAG-FLEX/3′USS-GFP). Make serial dilutions of the standard plasmid in 10-fold dilutions from 1 × 1010 to 1 × 107 copies/mL.
Dilute the vector solution at 1:100 and 1:1,000 with ddH2O.
Prepare the reaction mixture with TaqMan Master Mix.
Perform the real-time quantitative PCR and determine the vector titer based on the standard curve. See troubleshooting 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.1] and 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.3].

Intracranial injection of the vectors
Timing: 1 day

Here we describe how to prepare the surgical supplies, stereotaxic instruments, and glass micropipettes, and mention the method for stereotactic injection of AAV vector solution into the striatum of the wild-type (Long Evans) and parvalbumin (PV)-Cre knockin rats, in which Cre recombinase is expressed under the control of the PV gene promoter. AAV vectors were introduced into the striatum (4 sites), and the anteroposterior (AP), mediolateral (ML), and dorsoventral (DV) coordinates (mm) from bregma and dura were 1.5/3.0/3.0 (site 1), 1.5/3.0/3.5 (site 2), 0.5/3.0/3.0 (site 3), and 0.5/3.0/3.5 (site 4) according to an atlas of the rat brain.12[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib12] A set of stereotaxic injection into the rat brain is shown in Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3].
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/3088-Fig3.jpg
Figure 3. Intracranial injection of AAV vectors
(A) Overall view of AAV vector injection into the rat brain. A deeply anesthetized rat is placed in a stereotaxic instrument to inject AAV vector solution into the brain region. 1) isoflurane anesthesia apparatus; 2) stereotaxic instrument; 3) microinfusion pump, and 4) micropipette manipulator.
(B) Injection of AAV vector solution is performed by inserting the glass micropipette into the brain region according to the coordinates from bregma and dura.
Sterilize surgical instruments and supplies such as forceps, fine scissors, and swabs by using an autoclave.
Sterilize the surgical area with a sterilizing disinfectant.
Prepare the glass micropipettes (10 cm in length, 1.0 mm in outer diameter, 0.75 mm in inner diameter) for vector injection.
Pull borosilicate glass capillary using a micropipette puller (Model PC-10, NARISHIGE). The parameter of a pulling program is: Step1, Level at 65.
Cut the pipette tip with scissors (outer diameter of the tip: 12–14 μm).
Apply the anesthesia to a rat and fix the head in a stereotaxic instrument.

Anesthetize the rat intraperitoneally (i.p.) with the mixed anesthetic solution including medetomidine (0.04 mg/kg), midazolam (0.4 mg/kg) and butorphanol (0.4 mg/kg).
Place the rat in a sealed anesthesia induction chamber and supply 4% isoflurane for 3–5 min.
Note: The anesthetic solution should be stored at 4°C within 8 weeks.
Shave the head with an electric clipper/trimmer, being careful not to wake up from the anesthesia.
Fix the head to the stereotaxic frame with two ear bars and a nose clamp.
Attach the anesthesia head holder and supply 1.5% isoflurane.
Confirm that the rat is in deep anesthesia by monitoring the toe reflex. If there is no reflex, isoflurane concentration can be lowered to 1%.
Monitor deep anesthesia with periodic toe-pinches during surgery.
Apply eye lubricant to protect eyes from drying.
Determine the drilling points in the rat brain.
Wipe the head with 70% ethanol to remove any hair left on the skin after shaving.
Disinfect the scalp with 10% povidone-iodine at least three times.
Incise the scalp with thin scissors (approximately 20-mm length).
Clean the skull with a cotton swab dipped in sterile PBS so that bregma and lambda are clearly visible.
Note: Bregma is the intersection of the coronal and sagittal sutures of the skull, and lambda is the intersection of the lambdoid and sagittal sutures. For accurate anatomical positioning of the brain, both the anteroposterior (AP) and mediolateral (ML) axes of the skull must be horizontal to the plate of the stereotaxic instrument.
Adjust the tilt of the head so that bregma and lambda are in the same horizontal plane.
Note: The difference between the dorsoventral (DV) coordinates of bregma and lambda should be less than 0.05 mm.
Set the coordinates of the bregma as the origin of the coordinates.

Connect the 0.5-mm round stereotaxic drill to the stereotaxic manipulator.
Rotate the AP and ML modulators and position them so that the drill tip moves to the coordinates over the left or right striatum.
Rotate slowly the DV modulator under the surgical microscope and lower the drill until the tip of the drill reaches the skull surface.
Drill into the skull carefully and slowly while looking through the surgical microscope.
Note: Drill through the targeted skull point until the dura mater, which lies beneath the skull, is visible. The dura mater is often punctured during drilling. If not, the mater is ruptured with a 25-gauge needle tip. Be careful not to damage the brain parenchyma.
Critical: Bleeding may occur when puncturing the skull. In this case, stop the bleeding by pressing the hole with a small cotton swab dipped in sterile, cold PBS. Bone debris and excess blood should be washed away. Before injecting the vectors, cover the hole with a sterile PBS-soaked cotton to moisten the surface of the brain.
Inject AAV vector solution into the brain regions.
Fill the glass micropipette with Fluorinert (Sumitomo 3M), and connect to the Hamilton syringe through the teflon tube.
Thaw the AAV vector solution on ice.
Critical: Avoid multiple freeze-thaw cycles of AAV solution to prevent a loss of transduction efficiency of vectors. If the same vector solution is used within a week, store it at 4°C.
Pull the plunger of the Hamilton syringe to draw up the vector solution into the glass micropipette.
Set the glass micropipette to a stereotaxic manipulator.

Move the glass micropipette over the hole in the left or right striatum and slowly rotate the DV modulator to lower the tip so that the tip is close to the surface of the brain, and set the surface as a reference point for the DV coordinate.
Penetrate the brain by lowering the tip of the glass micropipette until it reaches the depth of the striatum from the surface.
Note: Once the tip of the glass micropipette reaches the striatum, leave it for 1–2 min.
Inject 500 nL of vector solution into the striatum at a flow rate of 50–100 nL/min.
Placed the glass micropipette in the end position to spread the vector for an additional 5 min to prevent the solution backflow.
Retract slowly the glass micropipette until the tip is completely away from the skull.
Repeat as above for other striatal regions.
Close the wound with medical surgical sutures.
Apply 0.1% GENTACIN Ointement to the suture to prevent surgical would infection.
Return the rat to the home cage.
Note: It is better to keep the rat on a heating pad until waking up from the anesthesia.
Observe the rat’s health after the awakening.
Allow at least 2 weeks for transgene expression.
Detection of transgene expression
Timing: 7 days
In this section, we describe the methods for perfusion, brain sectioning, and double immunofluorescence histochemistry.
Perfuse the rat ∼2 weeks after vector injection for fixation.
Anesthetize the rat i.p. with the mixed anesthetic solution including medetomidine (0.04 mg/kg), midazolam (0.4 mg/kg) and butorphanol (0.4 mg/kg).
Place the rat in the sealed anesthesia induction chamber and supply 4% isoflurane for 3–5 min.
Move the rat on a perfusion plate and open the thoracic cavity with thin scissors to expose the heart.

Insert a 25-gauge needle into the left ventricle and make a small incision in the right atrium with the scissors.
Perfuse 200 mL of ice-cold 0.1 M PB with a peristaltic pump.
Note: 0.1 M PB should be stored at 4°C within 1 year.
Perfuse 200 mL of ice-cold 10% formalin neutral buffer solution at a flow rate of 10 mL/min.
Remove the brain and immerse it in 10% formalin solution at 4°C for 16–24 h.
Replace the formalin solution by 10% sucrose in PBS and allow the brain to equilibrate completely at 4°C for 1 day.
Replace with 20% sucrose in PBS and shake gently at 4°C for 1–2 days until the brain is completely submerged.
Repeat similarly with 30% sucrose in PBS.
Make sections of the brain tissue.
Cut off the brainstem so that the hemispheres are flattened in the case of coronal sectioning.
Place a drop of OCT compound on the fixation plate in a chilled cryostat and attach the brain to the plate, directing the olfactory bulb upwards.
Pour carefully the OCT compound over the brain.
Leave the embedded brain in the cryostat for 20–30 min.
Attach the plate with the brain to the holder of the cryostat.
Section the brain into 30-μm thickness (through the striatum) and transfer the sections into PBS with a paintbrush.
Incubate the sections with the primary antibodies and species-specific secondary antibodies conjugated to Alexa 488 or Cy3.
Transfer the sections into 5% normal swine serum in PBS and block nonspecific binding for 30–60 min at 24°C–26°C.
Incubate the sections for 12–24 h at 4°C with goat polyclonal anti-GFP antibody (1:4000 dilution) and rabbit polyclonal anti-PV antibody (1:200 dilution) in 500 μL of PBS containing 0.3% Triton-X.
Wash the sections in PBS for 5 min 3 times

Incubate the sections for 2 h at 24°C–26°C with Alexa 488-conjugated goat-IgG antibody (1:1000 dilution) and Cy3-conjugated rabbit IgG antibody (1:1000 dilution) in 500 μL PBS containing 0.3% Triton-X.
Wash the sections in PBS for 5 min twice.
Stain the nuclei with 2 mL of 1 μg/mL DAPI in PBS for 5 min at 24°C–26°C.
Wash the sections in PBS for 5 min twice.
Mount the sections on gelatin-coated glass slides.
Apply a coverslip with a mounting medium for fluorescence microscopy.
Note: The sections can be stored at −20°C for approximately 2 years.
Visualize the signals with a confocal laser-scanning microscope (Nikon A1) equipped with proper filter cube specifications. See troubleshooting 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.5] and 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.7].
Count the number of immunostained cells in the regions of interest.
The efficiency of transgene expression in target cell types is evaluated by the percentage of the number of PV+ + GFP+ cells divided by the total number of PV+ cells.
The selectivity of transgene expression in target cell types is validated by the percentage of the number of PV- + GFP+ cells divided by the total number of GFP+ cells.
